metadata.case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee & Ors.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee was in the insurance line since June 1941, confirmed in service by Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. in March 1950, working as Inspector since about 1953, and holding appointment as Inspector at Barrackpore since March 18, 1955.
Life Insurance Corporation took over controlled business of Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. and terminated services of Mukherjee by order dated October 16, 1958.

Appointment as whole-time Inspector by Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. on March 18 or 19, 1955, governed by document with 14 clauses (Annexure A), Clause 13 providing termination without notice for misconduct, or 30 days notice otherwise.

Order dated February 14, 1958, by Divisional Manager appointing Mukherjee as Field Officer in terms of Government Order No. 53(1)/I.S.N.(1)/57 dated December 30, 1957, attached to Barrackpore Branch Office until further orders.

Termination order dated October 16, 1958, stating in terms of section 5 of Categorisation circular of December 2, 1957, case examined by Special Committee appointed by Board, recommendations accepted, services terminated with immediate effect, paid emoluments up to current month and one month's salary in lieu of notice.

Mukherjee filed writ petition under Article 226 in Calcutta High Court praying for certiorari or other writ quashing termination order; Sinha J. allowed petition, issued certiorari and mandamus directing implementation.
Appellants preferred Letters Patent appeal before Division Bench (Bose C.J. and Debabrata Mookerji J.), which confirmed Sinha J.'s order; certificate of fitness obtained for appeal to Supreme Court.
Facts substantially similar in all 15 appeals.

Life Insurance (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance No. 1 of 1956 promulgated January 19, 1956; replaced by Act No. 9 of 1956 effective March 21, 1956; followed by Act 31 of 1956 published July 1, 1956, appointed date September 1, 1956.
Section 7 of Act 31 of 1956 transferred assets and liabilities of controlled business to Corporation on appointed day.

Section 11(1) provided whole-time employees of insurers became employees of Corporation on appointed day, holding office by same tenure, remuneration, terms, conditions, rights as before, until terminated or altered.

Central Government order dated December 30, 1957 (blue order) under s.11(2), Life Insurance Corporation Field Officers (Alteration of Remuneration and other Terms and Conditions of Service) Order, 1957, applying to Field Officers/Development Officers.
Circulars by Managing Director: September 30, 1957 and December 2, 1957; latter incorporated via Regulations.
Regulations framed in 1958 under s.49 read with clause 11 of Order; Regulation 4(3) refers to December 2, 1957 circular for judging work.

Paragraph 4(h) of December 2, 1957 circular: For performance less than 50% of revised quota, cases referred to Zonal Committee; may terminate services if poor performance not due to circumstances beyond control, no efforts shown.
No enquiry held and no opportunity given under clause 10(a) of Order before termination in any case; not under clause 10(b).

Haridas Roy (C.A. No. 917/1963): Employed by Hindustan Co-operative Insurance Society Ltd. as Inspector of Agents; appointed Field Officer February 15, 1958; August 9, 1958 offered absorption as Assistant, declined; services terminated September 18, 1958 with one month's salary in lieu of notice.

legal_issues.text: Whether the orders terminating services of respondents (ex-employees of insurers who became employees of Corporation) were valid, particularly whether termination under paragraph 4(h) of the Categorisation circular (incorporated in Regulations) was independent of or required compliance with clause 10 of the 1957 Order.
Effect of the order dated February 14, 1958 appointing respondent as Field Officer.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in holding termination orders invalid; terminations valid under paragraph 4(h) and paragraph 5 of December 2, 1957 circular (incorporated in Regulations via Regulation 4(3)), independent of clause 10 of the Order; applied to incompetent/unwilling Field Officers in interests of Corporation and policy-holders.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 11(2) of Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956; 1957 Order clause 11; 1958 Regulations

petitioner_arguments.text: For Haridas Roy, termination valid under para 4(h) or s.11(2).

respondent_arguments.text: Termination of services can only be under clause 10(a) or 10(b) of the 1957 Order; since neither complied with (no enquiry/opportunity under 10(a), no prior approval of Chairman under 10(b)), orders invalid.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.11(1), employees transferred with same terms/conditions until altered; s.11(2) empowers Central Government to alter terms notwithstanding s.11(1) or other laws, and if not acceptable, terminate with 3 months compensation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Employees became Corporation employees on same terms until Order issued.

court_reasoning.text: 1957 Order (under s.11(2)) provides self-contained code for Field/Development Officers' terms; clause 10 specifically governs penalties/termination: 10(a) for misconduct/negligence after opportunity/enquiry; 10(b) without reason but with Chairman's approval and 3 months notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Termination must comply with clause 10(a) or (b).

court_reasoning.text: Regulations under s.49 read with clause 11 of Order valid for fixing pay/allowances per clause 5; circular incorporated for judging performance to fit into pay scale, but para 4(h) cannot authorize termination independent of clause 10, else inconsistent and invalid; must read as requiring clause 10 compliance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Para 4(h) reconciled with clause 10; termination for incompetence requires clause 10 procedure.

court_reasoning.text: Hierarchy: s.11(2) paramount, then Order (like rules under s.48), then Regulations (cannot contradict Act/Order).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Regulations limited to pay fixation within Development Officer category.

court_reasoning.text: Haridas Roy case not distinguishable: absorption offer as Assistant beyond Regulations' scope; termination invalid as non-compliant with clause 10.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Could fix minimum pay under clause 5; refusal might trigger s.11(2).

holdings.text: Termination orders invalid for non-compliance with clause 10(a) or (b) of 1957 Order, even if under para 4(h) of circular.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs transfer of business, employees, alteration of terms, regulations; paramount over Order and Regulations.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition; Art.311 claim raised but relief on alternative ground.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Field Officers (Alteration of Remuneration and other Terms and Conditions of Service) Order, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Alters terms for Field/Development Officers; clause 10 governs termination.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Staff Regulations, 1960; 1958 Regulations under s.49
statutes_cited.relevance: Fix pay/allowances per Order clause 11 and clause 5; incorporates circular.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the 15 appeals filed by Life Insurance Corporation, confirmed the Calcutta High Court's orders quashing the termination orders and issuing writs of certiorari and mandamus.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court orders confirmed: writs quashing terminations and directing Corporation to give effect.

key_quotes.text: "the termination of the services of the said officers must be effected in the manner prescribed by clause 10 of the Order."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding reconciling circular with Order.

key_quotes.text: "in regard to the termination of services of the employees, clause 10 has made a specific provision, and wherever the Corporation wants to terminate the services of any Development Officer, clause 10 has to be complied with."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the said portion of paragraph 4 h is interpreted to mean that it confers on the Corporation an authority to terminate the services of the Development Officer independently of clause 10 of the Order, it would be inconsistent with the said clause and would, therefore, be invalid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains invalidity of independent termination power.
